title: Windy Gyle Walking Route

images.title: Christine Westerback / Reaching the Top of Windy Gyle
images.caption: Reaching the Top of Windy Gyle. A steep climb then fantastic views

images.title: Eileen Henderson / Pennine Way on Windy Gyle
images.caption: Pennine Way on Windy Gyle. View along the long-distance footpath from the west slope of Windy Gyle. The border fence is on the left of the photo.

images.title: Dave Dunford / Bridleway, Windy Gyle
images.caption: Bridleway on the Gyle. Looking ESE towards Scotchman's Ford from below Russell's Cairn

images.title: Kenneth   Ross / Summit of Windy Gyle
images.caption: Summit of Windy Gyle. Looking east to the Cheviot

images.title: Chris Heaton / Windy Gyle Summit
images.caption: Summit view at 2034 ft. Passed by the Pennine Way to the right. The England/Scotland border also cuts across this lofty place

images.title: Andy Stephenson / Mozie Law path junction
images.caption: Mozie Law path junction. Between Windy Gyle and Mozie Law in the Cheviot Hills. An important junction: the path from Barrowburn joins the Pennine Way here. Altitude: 1670 feet.

images.title: Neil Turnbull / Windy Gyle summit cairn
images.caption: Summit cairn Looking roughly south east on a fine August day. The signpost indicates the direction of the Pennine Way. On my OS map the cairn seems to be named Russell's Cairn.

images.title: Kenneth   Ross / Beef Stand looking to Black Braes and Windy Gyle
images.caption: Beef Stand looking to Black Braes and the Gyle. An area of isolated rough grazing south of Beef Stand Hill. The name suggests cattle were kept here in days gone by. A remote area of a similar nature in the Moffat Hills is also called Beef Stand and was used as hiding place for stolen cattle in the historical days of the Reivers (Cattle Raiders) on the English-Scottish Border.

description: Climb to the summit of this hill in the Cheviots and enjoy fabulous views into Scotland and England as you stand high on the border. This challenging circular route runs for a distance of about 10 miles using the bridleways and footpaths that cross the area. The walk begins from the Wedder Leap car park and heads towards Shorthope hill, crossing the River Coquet and following the Rowhope Burn as you go. You continue the climb to Little Ward Law before coming to Russel's Cairn at the 619 m (2,031 ft) summit of Windy Gyle. From here there are wonderful views over the Scottish Borders, the Eildon Hills and Edinburgh. You begin the descent by heading west along the Pennine Way and then south towards Swineside Law and Hindside Knowe. Shortly after you cross the River Coquet and return to the car park. This is a challenging walk but the footpaths are generally good and you're rewarded with some stunning scenery. To continue your walking in the Cheviots you could climb the highest hill - The Cheviot .
